extractedContent:
Application Number: 242887
Filename: CODMAN SQUARE HEALTH CENTER, INC_Application-242887.pdf
Processed: 2026-01-23T00:54:27.120Z

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.evidence: In the Project Narrative, CSHC states: 'In August 2023, CSHC contracted Health Resources in Action (HRiA), a non-profit public health organization in Boston, to lead the development of the 2023 community health needs assessment (CHNA). The 2023 CHNA was undertaken to ensure that CSHC is addressing the most pressing health concerns among residents of its primary service area of Dorchester, MA. ... Our last CHNA performed in 2023 was conducted by Health Resources in Action (HRiA)... Our next CHNA will be undertaken in 2026 calendar year.' The application further describes the use of multiple data sources, including UDS, Boston Public Health Commission, Massachusetts Health Policy Commission, and Massachusetts League of Community Health Centers, and details how the needs assessment informs service delivery, strategic planning, and community engagement. The application also describes annual review of the service area and ongoing assessment of unmet need.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear evidence that a comprehensive needs assessment was completed in 2023, within the required three-year interval, and that it utilized current data sources relevant to the service area and special populations. The narrative describes how the needs assessment is used to inform and improve the delivery of services, and outlines a process for regular updates and integration into planning. There is also evidence of annual review and ongoing monitoring of patient needs and service area changes. Therefore, the application is COMPLIANT with Element b - Update of Needs Assessment.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13 - Health Center Program Compliance states: 'CSHC has developed and adopts a Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) in compliance with the Health Center Program Requirements which is applicable to all patients based on family size and household income, to ensure costs do not present a barrier to care. All patients who seek care at CSHC are assured that they will be served regardless of their ability to pay. No one is refused service because of a lack of financial means to pay.' The narrative further details definitions of income and family, methods for assessing eligibility, and policies related to nominal charges. Form 1C lists 'Sliding Fee Discount Program policies, operating procedures, and sliding fee schedule.' Attachment 10 provides the Sliding Fee Discount Schedule. The Board's authority to approve policies is documented in Attachment 2: Bylaws (Section V.e, VI.d, VI.e, VI.i). Annual review and approval by the Board is referenced in the narrative and budget narrative.
compliantItems.reasoning: There is clear, direct evidence that CSHC has board-approved SFDP policies, that these policies apply uniformly to all patients, and that they address all required areas (definitions, eligibility, nominal charges, annual review, etc.). The policies are referenced in multiple attachments, and the Board's authority and process for policy approval are documented in the bylaws.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 5A - Required Services Provided shows that all required services (medical, dental, behavioral health, pharmacy, etc.) are provided directly (Column I) or by contract, and the narrative in Attachment 13 confirms that the SFDS is applied to all services provided directly. Attachment 10 - Sliding Fee Discount Schedule details the discount structure by FPL bracket, including nominal fees for ≤100% FPL and graduated discounts up to 200% FPL. The narrative in Attachment 13 and the Project Narrative confirm that the SFDS is applied after insurance adjudication and is consistent with board-approved policy.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application demonstrates that the SFDS is applied to all direct services (Column I), with a structure that matches policy and HRSA requirements (nominal fee for ≤100% FPL, sliding scale for 101–200% FPL, etc.). The SFDS is reviewed and approved annually, and the policy is implemented as described.

compliantItems.element: Element e - Incorporation of Current Federal Poverty Guidelines
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 10 - Sliding Fee Discount Schedule is labeled '2025 SLIDING FEE DISCOUNT SCALE EFFECTIVE 3-1-2025' and references 'Federal Register published 01-17-2025: Annual Update of the HHS Poverty guidelines on or after January 15, 2025.' The narrative in Attachment 13 states: 'CSHC's SFDP is closely aligned with the current Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG) and is applied across all service areas, including medical, dental and behavioral health. The SFDP is typically revised for an effective date of March 1, following the issuance date of the FRG notice.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The SFDS uses the most recent FPG, as evidenced by the explicit reference to the 2025 Federal Register update and the effective date. The policy and schedule are updated annually to reflect the current FPG, as required.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Documentation of Key Management Staff Positions
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4 - Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff includes detailed job descriptions for all key management staff (CEO, CFO, COO, CHRO, CIO, CMO, CACO, CNO), specifying responsibilities and required qualifications. Attachment 5 - Biographical Sketches for Key Management Staff provides resumes/biographical information demonstrating the training and experience of each key manager. The Project Narrative (Capacity section) references these attachments and summarizes the qualifications and duties of each key management staff member. Form 2 - Staffing Profile lists the key management staff and their FTEs.
compliantItems.reasoning: HRSA requires that key management staff position descriptions include both duties/functions and qualification requirements, and that the health center demonstrates that individuals in these roles meet those requirements. The application provides position descriptions for all key management staff, outlining both duties and qualifications. Biographical sketches confirm that the individuals meet or exceed the stated qualifications. The Project Narrative and Form 2 corroborate the existence and direct employment of these positions. Therefore, the documentation requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4 - Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff: The CEO position description states the CEO reports to the Board of Directors, is accountable for overall performance, and oversees all operations and staff. Attachment 5 - Biographical Sketches: Guy Fish, MD, MBA is listed as CEO/Project Director. Project Narrative (Capacity section) states: 'The CEO is directly employed by CSHC, reports to the Board, and oversees the Executive Leadership Team.' The Bylaws (Attachment 2) Section VI(c) and XXXI specify the Board hires, evaluates, and can dismiss the CEO, who is accountable to the Board and responsible for day-to-day operations. Form 2 - Staffing Profile lists the CEO as a direct hire (1.0 FTE). The Organizational Chart (Attachment 3) shows the CEO at the top, reporting to the Board, with all other executives reporting to the CEO.
compliantItems.reasoning: HRSA requires the CEO/Project Director to be directly employed by the health center, report to the governing board, and have authority over day-to-day operations and key management staff. The application provides clear, multiple sources of evidence: the CEO is a direct employee (not contracted), reports to the Board (per Bylaws and Org Chart), and is responsible for all operations and staff. The position description and narrative confirm these responsibilities. The CEO's employment and reporting structure are fully compliant with HRSA requirements.

compliantItems.element: Element e - HRSA Approval for Contracting Substantive Programmatic Work
compliantItems.requirement: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: a) Contract(s) with another organization to perform substantive programmatic work within the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No'. The application narrative (Attachment 13 - Health Center Program Compliance) states: 'Not applicable to CSHC as it does not utilize any subrecipients or subawards.' Attachment 7 - Summary of Contracts and Agreements lists many contracts, but none meet the HRSA definition of a single entity providing the majority of health care providers (i.e., substantive programmatic work).
compliantItems.reasoning: The applicant does not contract for substantive programmatic work as defined by HRSA (i.e., contracting with a single entity for the majority of health care providers). All contracts listed are for discrete services or specialty providers, not for the majority of required health services. The applicant correctly answered 'No' on Form 8 and provided supporting narrative. Therefore, the requirement is met.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 7 - Summary of Contracts and Agreements provides detailed descriptions of each contract/agreement, including: description of services, timeframe, and process for tracking patients for follow-up care. The Project Narrative (Contracts and Subawards section) states: 'Written contracts for required and additional clinical services provided via Column II include the following components: specific services or activities to be performed or provided, compensation, number of sessions, documentation of services delivered in the patient's electronic health record, billing for services space, supplies and equipment, term of service, separability and termination of service, liability insurance, provider credentialing and monitoring contractor performance.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The applicant provides a summary table (Attachment 7) for all contracts, and the narrative confirms that all required contract provisions are included in written agreements. This meets the HRSA requirement for contract provisions supporting the approved scope of project.

notApplicableItems.element: Element g - HRSA Approval to Subaward (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize...subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' Attachment 13 - Health Center Program Compliance states: 'Not applicable to CSHC as it does not utilize any subrecipients or subawards.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The applicant does not utilize any subawards or subrecipients. This is confirmed in both the narrative and Form 8. Therefore, this requirement is not applicable.

notApplicableItems.element: Element h - Subaward Agreement (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize...subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' Attachment 13 - Health Center Program Compliance states: 'Not applicable to CSHC as it does not utilize any subrecipients or subawards.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The applicant does not utilize any subawards or subrecipients. This is confirmed in both the narrative and Form 8. Therefore, this requirement is not applicable.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.evidence: The Project Narrative, especially the 'COLLABORATION' section, details extensive collaboration with local hospitals (Boston Medical Center, Brigham and Women's Hospital), specialty providers (psychiatry, podiatry, cardiology, etc.), and social service organizations (Codman Square Neighborhood Development Corporation, Action for Boston Community Development, Harbor Health Services/WIC, etc.). Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements provides a comprehensive list of formal written agreements with these entities, specifying the services provided, the nature of the collaboration, and the process for tracking patient follow-up. Letters of support from these organizations (Attachment 9: Collaboration Documentation) further confirm active, ongoing partnerships. The narrative describes how these collaborations ensure access to services not available directly at the health center, such as specialty care, inpatient services, and enabling services for special populations.
compliantItems.reasoning: There is clear, detailed, and multi-faceted evidence of both formal and informal collaborative relationships with a wide range of providers and programs in the service area. The documentation includes both narrative descriptions and formal agreements, as well as third-party letters of support. The partnerships address access to services not available at the health center, including specialty and hospital-based care, and social services for special populations. This meets the requirement for coordination and integration of activities.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Collaboration with Other Primary Care Providers
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.evidence: The Project Narrative (COLLABORATION section) and Attachment 9: Collaboration Documentation provide extensive documentation of collaboration with other HRSA-funded health centers in the service area, including DotHouse Health, Dimock Community Health Center, Harvard Street Neighborhood Health Center, Mattapan Community Health Center, Brockton Neighborhood Health Center, Upham's Corner Health Committee, and others. Letters of support from these health centers are included. The application describes participation in Boston HealthNet (a Health Center Controlled Network), Boston Accountable Care Organization (BACO), and the Massachusetts League of Community Health Centers (the state PCA), all of which facilitate ongoing coordination and integration of activities among FQHCs and other safety net providers. The service area map (Attachment 1) and narrative explicitly note intentional overlap and coordination with other FQHCs to ensure a 'no wrong door' approach for patients. There is also documentation of collaboration with state and local health departments and public health programs.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides robust evidence of ongoing, intentional, and formal collaboration with other federally-funded, state, and local health services delivery projects and programs serving similar populations. The relationships with other health centers are well-documented through both narrative and letters of support, and the participation in HCCNs, ACOs, and the PCA further demonstrates integration and coordination. This meets the requirement for collaboration with other primary care providers.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Participation in Insurance Programs
compliantItems.requirement: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13 - Health Center Program Compliance, Billing and Collections section: 'CSHC is a certified Medicare provider, as such it adheres to all billing guidelines and regulations set forth by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), ensuring that all documentation is submitted accurately and on time. Similarly, as a Medicaid provider, CSHC complies with Massachusetts requirements and guidelines, working closely with MassHealth, Massachusetts' Medicaid agency, to align billing practices with their standards. In Massachusetts, Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) are combined into MassHealth, which allows CSHC to provide healthcare services to children from low-income families, with our billing team proficient in CHIP regulations to ensure correct claim processing. In addition to these public assistance programs, CSHC contracts with various private health insurance companies.' Also, Form 3 - Income Analysis shows revenue from Medicaid, Medicare, Other Public, Private, and Self Pay.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear, direct evidence that CSHC actively participates in Medicaid (MassHealth), CHIP (as part of MassHealth), Medicare, and private insurance programs. The billing and collections narrative details compliance with all relevant billing requirements, and Form 3 shows income from these payers. This meets the HRSA requirement for participation in insurance programs.

compliantItems.element: Element h - Policies or Procedures for Waiving or Reducing Fees
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13 - Health Center Program Compliance, Billing and Collections section: 'CSHC has board-approved policies and procedures in place to ensure that no patient is denied access to care due to an inability to pay. These policies include financial counseling, assistance with insurance enrollment, and eligibility screening for the Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP), as well as other forms of financial support.' ... 'CSHC's billing and collection policies explicitly state that fees will be reduced or waived based on specific circumstances, including financial hardship. Patients may request a Waiver, and staff will assist in completing the necessary documentation for consideration.' Also, Form 1C - Documents On File lists 'Billing and Collections policies/procedures, including those regarding waivers or fee reductions and refusal to pay.' The Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) and Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (Attachment 10) are board-approved and reviewed annually.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides explicit evidence of board-approved policies and procedures for waiving or reducing fees, including a process for patients to request waivers due to inability to pay. The policies are reviewed annually, and staff are trained to assist patients. The presence of a sliding fee discount schedule, waiver policy, and documentation of board approval and review all support compliance with this HRSA requirement.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Budgeting for Scope of Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: The application includes a detailed SF-424A Budget Information form, a comprehensive Budget Narrative, and multi-year budget tables showing both federal and non-federal revenue and expenses. The budget narrative explicitly states: 'The proposed budget is strategically designed to support the goals and activities outlined in the RESPONSE section - which serves as its general workplan - and reflects a clear alignment with the scope and scale of the proposed project.' The budget aligns with the projected patient and visit volumes (Form 1A, Budget Narrative), and the budget categories (personnel, fringe, supplies, contractual, other, indirect) are consistent with the described scope of services and staffing (see Form 2: Staffing Profile, Form 5A: Services Provided). The Board of Directors is documented as having responsibility for approving the annual budget (Attachment 2: Bylaws, Section V(e)).
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center has submitted a complete annual budget that covers all projected costs and revenues for the scope of project, as required. The budget is consistent across all required documents, aligns with the work plan and projected service levels, and is Board-approved. There is no evidence of missing or inadequate budget information.

compliantItems.requirement: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: The SF-424A, Budget Narrative, and Form 3: Income Analysis all include detailed breakdowns of revenue sources beyond the HRSA award. These include state funds, local funds, other support (private grants/contracts, contributions, other), and program income (fees, third party reimbursements, and payments generated from the projected delivery of services). For example, Form 3, Part 2 lists State Government ($957,864), Local Government ($1,344,704), Private Grants/Contracts ($5,108,442), Contributions ($1,052,017), Other ($26,804,505), and Program Income ($24,471,872), with totals matching the SF-424A and Budget Narrative. The narrative also describes the methodology for projecting program income and other sources, and the Board is documented as reviewing and approving the budget (Attachment 2: Bylaws, Section V(e)).
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center's annual budget includes all required revenue sources, both federal and non-federal, and these are consistently reported across all required forms. The budget narrative and forms provide sufficient detail to demonstrate that all revenue sources supporting the scope of project are included, as required by HRSA.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Maintenance of Board Authority Over Health Center Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Section VI (Board of Directors - Authority) states: 'The Board of Directors ... shall have the authority to manage and control the property and affairs of the Corporation.' Section VI further details specific authorities, including hiring and dismissing the CEO, adopting policies, approving budgets, and ensuring compliance with laws. The Project Narrative (Capacity section) and Attachment 3 (Organizational Chart) show the CEO reports directly to the Board, and the Board is the top authority in the organizational structure. There is no parent, affiliate, or subsidiary organization (Form 8), and the Board is not a co-applicant board.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws explicitly grant the Board full authority over the health center project, including all key oversight functions required by HRSA. The organizational chart and narrative confirm the Board's position at the top of the governance structure, with direct oversight of the CEO and all major decisions. No evidence of restrictions or outside control is present. Therefore, the health center is compliant with this element.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Required Authorities and Responsibilities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Section VI (Board of Directors - Authority) and Section V (Board of Directors) enumerate the Board's authorities and responsibilities, including: hiring/dismissing the CEO (VI.c), adopting personnel and financial policies (VI.d-e), approving budgets and applications (V.e), evaluating organizational performance (VI.f, VI.j), conducting needs assessments and strategic planning (VI.g), adopting health care policies (VI.i), ensuring compliance with laws (VI.h), and establishing/adopting policies (VI.d-e, VI.i). Attachment 13 (Health Center Program Compliance) cross-references these sections and confirms their presence. The Project Narrative (Governance section) also describes Board oversight, monthly meetings, and required functions.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws clearly and specifically enumerate all required authorities and responsibilities as outlined in the HRSA Compliance Manual, including those related to CEO oversight, policy adoption, budget approval, performance evaluation, and compliance. The application narrative and compliance crosswalk further confirm these are current and operational. Therefore, the health center is compliant with this element.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Sections VII (Board Number and Appointments), VIII (Election and Term), XVII (Removal), XVIII (Failure to Attend Meetings), XX (Vacancies), XXIV (Officers of Corporation - Election and Term), XXV-XXVII (Powers and Duties of President, President-Elect, Vice President). The bylaws specify that the Board elects its own members and officers, and removal is by Board action. No language allows any other entity, committee, or individual to select the board chair or a majority of members.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws clearly outline the process for selection and removal of board members and officers, with all authority vested in the Board itself. There is no evidence of any outside entity, committee, or individual having selection authority over the board chair or a majority of board members. This meets HRSA compliance requirements.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Section VII: Board must have 9-25 members; majority must be users/patients; user members must reasonably represent the patient population in terms of demographic factors; non-user members must represent the community and provide relevant expertise; no more than half of non-user members may derive >10% of income from health care industry; employees/contractors/immediate family of employees are prohibited.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws explicitly require all HRSA-mandated board composition elements, including size, patient majority, demographic representation, non-patient expertise, income limits, and prohibition of employees/contractors/family. This is fully compliant.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 6A: Current Board Member Characteristics; Project Narrative (Governance section); Attachment 2: Bylaws. Form 6A lists 10 board members, with at least 6 identified as health center patients (consumer majority), and demographic/area of expertise information. The narrative confirms the board meets all composition requirements.
compliantItems.reasoning: The board currently consists of 10 members, with a majority (at least 6) being patients, and the remainder providing relevant expertise. No more than half of non-patient members derive >10% of income from health care. The board reflects the community served. This meets HRSA requirements.

notApplicableItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 6B: Request for Waiver of Board Member Requirements states: 'This form is not applicable to you, since you are currently receiving or applying to receive Community Health Center (CHC) funding and/or you have selected 'Tribal' or 'Urban Indian' as the Business Entity in Form 1A.' Application is for 330(e) only.
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The applicant is only applying for 330(e) funding (Community Health Center) and is not requesting a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements. Therefore, this element is not applicable.
